title: Experimental Design: Burn Those Calories
question_text:
Is running on a treadmill for one hour or jumping rope for twenty minutes better at burning calories?
Which option below gives the most effective method at determining which treatment is better at burning calories?

choices.text: Let students volunteer which group they want to go in and compare the results.
Randomly separate the group and have half of them jump rope for twenty minutes while the other half runs on the treadmill for an hour.
Randomly divide the subjects into three groups. The first group will jump rope, the second group will run on the treadmill for twenty minutes, and the third group will do neither of the activities.
Randomly select which activity the entire group does on the first day followed by the different activity on the second day.

Randomly separate the group and have half on them jump rope for twenty minutes the first day and then run for an hour the next day. The other group will run for an hour the first day and jump rope for twenty minutes the next.

solution:
In this case, we are looking for the most effective method, which means we want to eliminate as many lurking and confounding variables as possible.

One thing to take into consideration is whether or not the subjects receive only one treatment or both treatments (running for twenty minutes and jumping rope). If we divide the subjects into two groups and have each of them only do one activity (one group does jump rope and the other runs for twenty minutes), this could present a problem.

By doing this, we could end up with a group where the metabolic rate is much faster than the other group. We would not be able to distinguish if it is the activity that burns more calories or if it is because the subjects had a higher metabolic rate. Therefore, we want to find a design where the subjects receive both treatments. Choices 'A', 'B', and 'C' can be eliminated.

Choice 'A' can be eliminated as this is a voluntary response bias.

Choice 'D' would not be the most effective method due to the fact something could happen in between the days that would not allow us to draw a proper conclusion. A variable to take into account would be that the subjects are fatigued and sore on the second day due to the first day's activity. We would not be able to distinguish if it was the first activity or the weariness on the second day that caused more calories being burnt on the first day.

Choice 'E' is the most effective as the groups were randomly divided and received both treatments.
